conclusion: Square ABCD with side length L, point charges at vertices: A: +q, B: +q, C: -q, D: -q. Need to find electric field at point O (center of the square).
The center of the square is equidistant from all four vertices.

premise: The center of the square is equidistant from all four vertices.
conclusion: The distance from the center to each vertex is r = L√2/2.
From charge A (+q): Repels positive charges, so field points away from A toward the center O.
From charge B (+q): Repels positive charges, so field points away from B toward the center O.
From charge C (-q): Attracts positive charges, so field points away from center O toward C.
From charge D (-q): Attracts positive charges, so field points away from center O toward D.

premise: The magnitude of the electric field due to a point charge q at a distance r is E = kq/r^2.
conclusion: For each charge, the magnitude is E_A = E_B = E_C = E_D = 2kq/L^2.
Set up a coordinate system with the center of the square at the origin, with the x-axis parallel to AB, and the y-axis parallel to AD.
The positions of the vertices in this coordinate system are: A: (-L/2, L/2), B: (L/2, L/2), C: (L/2, -L/2), D: (-L/2, -L/2).

premise: For each charge, the electric field has components.
conclusion: From A (+q): x-component: E_A,x = -E_A/√2, y-component: E_A,y = E_A/√2.

premise: For each charge, the electric field has components.
conclusion: From B (+q): x-component: E_B,x = -E_B/√2, y-component: E_B,y = -E_B/√2.

premise: For each charge, the electric field has components.
conclusion: From C (-q): x-component: E_C,x = E_C/√2, y-component: E_C,y = -E_C/√2.

premise: For each charge, the electric field has components.
conclusion: From D (-q): x-component: E_D,x = E_D/√2, y-component: E_D,y = E_D/√2.
